title: ion-modal
body: A Modal is a dialog that appears on top of the app's content, and must be dismissed by the app before interaction can resume. It is useful as a select component when there are a lot of options to choose from, or when filtering items in a list, as well as many other use cases.
The modal can be dismissed after creation by calling the
method on the modal controller. The
function can be called to perform an action after the modal is dismissed.
Modal uses scoped encapsulation, which means it will automatically scope its CSS by appending each of the styles with an additional class at runtime. Overriding scoped selectors in CSS requires a
We recommend passing a custom class to
method and using that to add custom styles to the host and inner elements. This property can also accept multiple classes separated by spaces. View the
section for an example of how to pass a class using
/* DOES NOT WORK - not specific enough */
/* Works - pass "my-custom-class" in cssClass to increase specificity */
can be used to style the Modal without needing to target individual elements:
If you are building an Ionic Angular app, the styles need to be added to a global stylesheet file. Read
in the Angular section below for more information.

After being dismissed, the data can be read in through the
attached to the modal after creation:
When lazy loading a modal, it's important to note that the modal will not be loaded when it is opened, but rather when the module that imports the modal's module is loaded.
For example, say there exists a
. The modal is presented by clicking a button in the
would need to be included in the
since the modal is created in the

Modals in iOS mode have the ability to be presented in a card-style and swiped to close. The card-style presentation and swipe to close gesture are not mutually exclusive, meaning you can pick and choose which features you want to use. For example, you can have a card-style modal that cannot be swiped or a full sized modal that can be swiped.
If you are creating an application that uses
, it is recommended that you get the parent
, otherwise the tabbar will not scale down when the modal opens.
is fine. In cases where you are presenting a card-style modal from within another modal, you should pass in the top-most
In Angular, the CSS of a specific page is scoped only to elements of that page. Even though the Modal can be presented from within a page, the
element is appended outside of the current page. This means that any custom styles need to go in a global stylesheet file. In an Ionic Angular starter this can be the
file or you can register a new global style file by
javascript:
<ion-header>
  <ion-toolbar>
    <ion-title>Modal Header</ion-title>
    <ion-buttons slot="primary">
      <ion-button onClick="dismissModal()">
        <ion-icon slot="icon-only" name="close"></ion-icon>
      </ion-button>
    </ion-buttons>
  </ion-toolbar>
</ion-header>
<ion-content class="ion-padding">
  Modal Content
</ion-content>
// create the modal with the `modal-page` component

props.name: backdropDismiss
props.docs: If true, the modal will be dismissed when the backdrop is clicked.

props.name: component
props.docs: The component to display inside of the modal.

props.name: componentProps
props.docs: The data to pass to the modal component.

props.name: cssClass
props.docs: Additional classes to apply for custom CSS. If multiple classes are provided they should be separated by spaces.

props.name: enterAnimation
props.docs: Animation to use when the modal is presented.

props.name: keyboardClose
props.docs: If true, the keyboard will be automatically dismissed when the overlay is presented.

props.name: leaveAnimation
props.docs: Animation to use when the modal is dismissed.

props.name: mode
props.docs: The mode determines which platform styles to use.

props.name: presentingElement
props.docs: The element that presented the modal. This is used for card presentation effects and for stacking multiple modals on top of each other. Only applies in iOS mode.

props.name: showBackdrop
props.docs: If true, a backdrop will be displayed behind the modal.

props.name: swipeToClose
props.docs: If true, the modal can be swiped to dismiss. Only applies in iOS mode.

methods.name: dismiss
methods.signature: dismiss(data?: any, role?: string | undefined) => Promise<boolean>
methods.docs: Dismiss the modal overlay after it has been presented.

docsTags.name: param
docsTags.text: data Any data to emit in the dismiss events.

docsTags.name: param
docsTags.text: role The role of the element that is dismissing the modal. For example, 'cancel' or 'backdrop'.

methods.name: onDidDismiss
methods.docs: Returns a promise that resolves when the modal did dismiss.

methods.name: onWillDismiss
methods.docs: Returns a promise that resolves when the modal will dismiss.

methods.name: present
methods.docs: Present the modal overlay after it has been created.

docs: A Modal is a dialog that appears on top of the app's content, and must be dismissed by the app before interaction can resume. It is useful as a select component when there are a lot of options to choose from, or when filtering items in a list, as well as many other use cases.

docsTags.text: {"ios" | "md"} mode - The mode determines which platform styles to use.
docsTags.name: virtualProp

events.docs: Emitted after the modal has dismissed.
Emitted after the modal has presented.
Emitted before the modal has dismissed.
Emitted before the modal has presented.

styles.name: --border-color
styles.docs: Border color of the modal content

styles.name: --border-radius
styles.docs: Border radius of the modal content

styles.name: --border-style
styles.docs: Border style of the modal content

styles.name: --border-width
styles.docs: Border width of the modal content
